section.title: Introduction
section.para: For many practical purposes it is not necessary to construct a complete parse tree for a sentence. Chunk parsing, also known as partial parsing light parsing, or just chunking, is an approach in which the parser assigns incomplete syntactic structure to the phrase. The most common use of chunking is in information extraction and message understanding, where the content of a text is mind for information that will be used to fill out a template. Chunk parsing is actually more like tagging than conventional parsing, in the sense that it typically uses finite-state methods and employs rules that work directly off the (tagged) surface string. This contrasts with conventional parsing, which normally uses context-free rules expressed over abstract categories (e.g. phrasal categories).
In terms of the other NLP tasks, chunking usually takes place after tokenization and tagging.

Typically, chunk parsers are based on finite-state methods. The constraints about well-formed chunks are expressed using regular expressions over the sequence of word tags. This tutorial describes the NLTK regular-expression chunk parser.

section.title: The Chunk Parser Interface
section.para: Unlike conventional parsers, a chunk parser does not return a tree but a simple structure showing where the chunks are. The most transparent Python representation is a list, consisting of a mixture of tokens and sublists. Here is an example of a chunk structure:

Thus, a chunker takes a list of tokens, and produces a list of (lists of) tokens. This generalization about chunkers is expressed in the
ChunkParserI class.

note.para: Note that this definition of chunk structure is too weak to express a more general kind of chunking which associates a type to each chunk. For example, there are chunkers which can identify both NP and VP chunks. For these it is necessary to define a more expressive representation.

section.para: All chunk parsers, including the REChunkParser class discussed below, should inherit from ChunkParserI and reimplement its parse method.

section.title: The Chunking Tokenizer
section.para: A common file representation for chunked tagged text is as follows:
section.programlisting: [ the/DT little/JJ cat/NN ] sat/VBD on/IN [ the/DT mat/NN ]
section.para:
It is often useful to be able to tokenize text input in this format as part of the evaluation process. For this purpose, the
token module contains a special kind of tagged tokenizer class, the
ChunkTaggedTokenizer.
section.programlisting:
&prompt; correct_sent = """ [ the/DT little/JJ cat/NN ] sat/VBD on/IN [ the/DT mat/NN ] """
&prompt; tokenizer = ChunkedTaggedTokenizer() &prompt; correct_chunks = tokenizer.tokenize(correct_sent) [['the'/'DT'@[1word], 'little'/'JJ'@[2word], 'cat'/'NN'@[3word]], 'sat'/'VBD'@[5word], 'on'/'IN'@[6word], ['the'/'DT'@[8word], 'mat'/'NN'@[9word]]]

section.title: The String Representation of Tokenized Sequences
section.para: Before we can apply a regular expression to a sequence of objects, those objects must first be encoded in a string. This presents a difficulty. We want to apply the chunker to the output of the tagger, and we want the output of the chunker simply add the chunking information. However, on the face of it, we must first project out the tags into a string, chunk the string, then somehow get back to the non-string representation. The following sequence of Python objects illustrate the dilemma:
section.programlisting:
# tagger output [ 'the'/'DT'@[1], 'cat'/'NN'@[2] 'sat'/'VBD'@[3], 'on'/'IN'@[4], 'the'/'DT'@[5], 'mat'/'NN'@[6] ]
# the list of tags [ 'DT', 'NN', 'VBD', 'IN', 'DT', 'NN' ]
# the string of tags ready for chunking 'DT NN VBD IN DT NN'
# the chunked tags '[DT NN] VBD IN [DT NN]'
# some black magic? [ [ 'the'/'DT'@[1], 'cat'/'NN'@[2] ], 'sat'/'VBD'@[3], 'on'/'IN'@[4], [ 'the'/'DT'@[5],'mat'/'NN'@[6] ] ]
section.para: The solution is to encode each token in a string which contains sufficient information for the token to be reconstructed, and then write chunking rules which only consider the tags, ignoring the types and the locations. The REChunkParser class provides a convenient interface hides this additional layer of complexity from the developer.

note.para: Note that no spaces are inserted between the encoded tokens. In the encoding, tokens are delimited with < and >, not with whitespace.

section.para: The chunker operates on this string, not by splitting it, but by inserting/removing chunk delimiters. The rechunkparser module uses braces as delimiters since, unlike parentheses and square brackets, these do not usually need to be backslash-escaped in regular expressions. The module provides a method called str2chunks which builds a chunk structure from this string. This is what is returned by the chunkparser for further processing, e.g. by an information extraction system.

It is possible to build an NLTK chunker based solely on the infrastructure provided above. However, we also provide classes to make it easier to express chunk rules and chunk parsers. The rest of the section discusses these.

section.title: Chunk Rules and Abstract Chunk Rules
section.para: Chunk rules operate on strings of encoded tokens to insert and delete the chunk delimiters. For instance, a rule might create a chunk by inserting { before the fifth token, and inserting } after the sixth token. Equally, a rule could combine two adjacent chunks by removing }{ from the string.

The
ChunkRule class provides a convenient wrapper for Python's built-in re (regular expression) class. The ChunkRule constructor takes five arguments:

listitem.para: target The material that the regular expression must apply to
action The action performed on this material (i.e. reproducing the material using the \1 construct and adding or removing braces).
left The left-hand context in which this rule applies.
right The right-hand context in which this rule applies.
doc Brief documentation of the function of the rule (e.g. 'chunking groups of JJ|NN').

section.para: Both target and action are explicit arguments. The remaining arguments are optional, keyword arguments. Here is a chunk rule which inserts the chunk delimiters around any tag NN.

note.para: Note that we use Python's raw string notation, so that the interpreter does not preprocess the backslash escapes. In general, it is a good idea to use the raw string notation whenever regular expressions are involved. We follow this practice here.

section.para: This rule matches tokens like <cat/NN@[1]>, and flags them as chunks by wrapping them with the chunk delimiters. This is probably the simplest kind of chunk rule, and it is already incomprehensible. Therefore, the rechunkparser module defines a more convenient interface, namely the AbstractChunkRule class.

The
AbstractChunkRule class is a simple wrapper for the ChunkRule class. AbstractChunkRule is a derived class whose initializer preprocesses its target, left and right arguments. The calling function can now employ regular expressions over the tags only, ignoring the fact that the string also contains types and locations. The first generalization is to note that the tags themselves have some internal structure that we can exploit. For example, a plural noun is tagged NNS. In some cases, there is no common prefix and so we are forced to use disjunction. Here is a chunk rule which puts chunk delimiters around any individual determiner, adjective or noun. (Adjacent chunks would then need to be merged by another rule.)

Now suppose we wished to create a single chunk which encompassed a sequence consisting of a determiner followed by zero or more adjectives, followed by a noun. We can also use the star operator for this:
In this example, the scope of the star operator is the preceding tag (i.e. the material contained inside the previous pair of angle brackets).

note.para: Note that the star and other regular expression operators behave differently depending on whether they are inside or outside the scope of the angle brackets. Inside the angle brackets, the operators work at the character level. Outside the angle brackets the operators apply to complete tags. In other words, the angle brackets are behaving like ordinary parentheses in regular expressions.

section.title: The REChunkParser Class
section.para:
The
REChunkParser allows the programmer to construct a chunkparser object from a list (or cascade) of chunk rules. Suppose we have a list of of rules and a list of tokens. Then we can construct a chunkparser and apply it as follows:

The parse method converts its argument to the string encoding, applies the chunk rules in sequence, then converts the result to a chunk structure and returns this structure. Here is a simple example using a rule we created earlier:
section.programlisting: &prompt; r1 = AbstractChunkRule(r'(<DT><JJ>*<NN>)', r'{\1}', doc="chunking <DT><JJ>*<NN>") &prompt; cp = REChunkParser([r1]) &prompt; chunked_sent = cp.parse(unchunked_sent) [['the'/'DT'@[1word], 'little'/'JJ'@[2word], 'cat'/'NN'@[3word]], 'sat'/'VBD'@[5word], 'on'/'IN'@[6word], ['the'/'DT'@[8word], 'mat'/'NN'@[9word]]]
section.para: The REChunkParser initializer has an optional second argument which is a debug flag. If this is set (e.g. to 1) then the chunk parser will display diagnostic output. We repeat the above example with the debug flag set:
section.programlisting:
&prompt; r1 = AbstractChunkRule(r'(<DT><JJ>*<NN>)', r'{\1}', doc="chunking <DT><JJ>*<NN>") &prompt; cp = REChunkParser([r1], 1) &prompt; chunked_sent = cp.parse(unchunked_sent)
chunking <DT><JJ>*<NN>: left: target: ((?:<[^/]*/(?:DT)@\d+>)(?:<[^/]*/(?:JJ)@\d+>)*(?:<[^/]*/(?:NN)@\d+>)) right: action: {\1} input: <DT> <JJ> <NN> <VBD> <IN> <DT> <NN> -> {<DT> <JJ> <NN>} <VBD> <IN> {<DT> <NN>}

section.title: Chunking Strategies
section.para: brute force vs iterative

Notes: in the brute force approach we construct complex regular expressions which create the desired chunks in a single step. In the iterative approach we create chunks, then successively merge and split them, until we get the desired result.
chunking vs chinking

Notes: chunking begins with an unchunked sentence and adds chunk delimiters. The dual approach, known as chinking begins with the entire sentence in a single chunk, then removes pieces. For example, we could chunk the whole sentence then chink the verbs using the following rule:
section.programlisting: AbstractChunkRule(r'(.*)', r'{\1}', doc='chunk the entire sentence') AbstractChunkRule(r'(<VB.*>)', r'}\1{', doc='chink the verbs')
section.para: Note the directionality of the braces in the second argument of the second constructor.

section.title: Evaluating Chunk Parsers
section.para: An easy way to evaluate a chunk parser is to take some already chunked text, strip off the chunks, rechunk it, and compare the result with the original chunked text. NLTK provides the necessary functions:
section.programlisting: unchunked_sent = unchunk(correct_chunks) chunker = REChunkParser(rules) chunked_sent = cp.parse(unchunked_sent) score(correct_chunks, chunked_sent)
section.para:
The
score function takes the correctly chunked sentence as its first argument, and the newly chunked version as its second argument, and compares them. It reports the fraction of actual chunks that were found (recall), the fraction of hypothesized chunks that were correct (precision), and a combined score, the F-measure (the harmonic mean of precision and recall).
